The Cat and Mouse Act was introduced in the United Kingdom in 1913 as a response to the suffragette movement. The act allowed for the release of hunger-striking suffragettes from prison to prevent them from becoming martyrs, but they could be re-arrested once they had recovered.

The Cat and Mouse Act was introduced in 1913.
